G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Hampden County and the damages exceed $50,000.

Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.raw_text: Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co., LLC, 467 Mass. 697, 700 (2014)
Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, “Every person is bound to exercise reasonable care to avoid naturally and probably injuring another person by his act.” Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co., LLC, 467 Mass. 697, 700 (2014).
Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is from a murder/criminal responsibility case and does not address general negligence or a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid naturally and probably injuring another. The quoted proposition is a tort-style reasonable care standard that is not discussed or articulated anywhere in this opinion. Thus, this case does not support the stated Massachusetts duty-of-care proposition, and the citation appears inaccurate or mismatched to the text given.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of care to maintain his property and possessions, including the ladder, in a manner that avoided creating an unreasonable risk of harm to others using the shared premises. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006) (duty arises when harm is foreseeable).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The case does support a duty of reasonable care tied to foreseeability, but it is materially narrower and fact-specific than the proposition as stated. Jupin imposes a duty on a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and grants unsupervised access to a person known to be violent and mentally unstable; it does not announce a general duty to maintain “property and possessions, including the ladder” on shared premises. The opinion concerns negligent firearm storage under highly specific circumstances, not a broad premises-maintenance duty for all objects on shared property.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “In consideration of emerging social customs and values, as well as appropriate social policy, we hold that a homeowner who permits a guest to keep guns permanently on her premises and allows a third person with a criminal history and mental difficulties unsupervised access to the property, has a duty to ensure that the firearms are properly and safely stored.” (447 Mass. at 153)

Griffin v. Loftin, 345 Mass. 683 (1963).proposition: Massachusetts law imposes liability for the negligent maintenance of property that foreseeably causes harm. See Griffin v. Loftin, 345 Mass. 683 (1963); Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013); and G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence statute).
Griffin v. Loftin, 345 Mass. 683 (1963).case_name: Morse v. Fall River Line Pier, Inc.
Griffin v. Loftin, 345 Mass. 683 (1963).support_reasoning: The opinion in Griffin v. Loftin concerns breach of an employment contract, de facto corporate directors, authority to bind a corporation, and damages on wrongful termination of a fixed-term employment contract. It does not address premises liability, negligent maintenance of property, foreseeability of physical harm, or comparative negligence. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that Massachusetts law imposes liability for the negligent maintenance of property that foreseeably causes harm.
Griffin v. Loftin, 345 Mass. 683 (1963).relevant_excerpt:
These are the defendant’s exceptions in an action of contract in which the plaintiff had a verdict for breach of a contract for his employment as pier manager for three years from March 1, 1957.
1. The defendant’s motion for a directed verdict was rightly denied.
The defendant relies on the absence of any action by directors valid to impose an obligation upon the corporation... ‘Where persons having color of title are permitted by the corporation to act in the position and with the reputation of being directors, third persons who deal with them... are entitled to assume that there is no defect in their appointment.’

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes liability for the negligent maintenance of property that foreseeably causes harm. See Griffin v. Loftin, 345 Mass. 683 (1963); Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013); and G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence statute).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that Massachusetts landowners owe a common-law duty of reasonable care, including an obligation to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition considering foreseeability of injury and seriousness of harm. It further holds that a landowner may be liable for negligently creating and maintaining an open and obvious dangerous condition when the landowner can and should anticipate that lawful entrants will encounter it and be harmed, which is precisely liability for negligent maintenance based on foreseeable harm. The court also expressly notes comparative negligence will reduce or bar recovery under G.L. c. 231, § 85.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ … Even if, on remand, the defendants are found to have owed and committed a breach of a duty of care, the plaintiff’s damages would be reduced by his comparative negligence … G. L. c. 231, § 85.”}

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes liability for the negligent maintenance of property that foreseeably causes harm. See Griffin v. Loftin, 345 Mass. 683 (1963); Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013); and G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence statute).

McDonough v. Whalen, 365 Mass. 506, 512.proposition: Defendant’s conduct directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s property damage, measured by the reasonable cost to repair the vehicle and related expenses. See McDonough v. Whalen, 365 Mass. 506, 512 (1974) (damages in negligence compensate for losses caused by defendant’s breach).
McDonough v. Whalen, 365 Mass. 506, 512.support_reasoning: The case does address property damage in negligence and requires proof that defendants’ negligence causally related to the property damage, but it does not discuss or define the measure of such damages as the reasonable cost to repair a vehicle or related expenses. It concerns real property damage (sewage over land, loss of use, depreciation, loss on resale), not motor vehicle damage, and the cited page merely confirms that plaintiffs may recover damages causally related to defendants’ negligence, not any specific formula for calculating those damages. Thus it supports the general causation/damages principle, but not the specific measure of property damage claimed in the proposition.
McDonough v. Whalen, 365 Mass. 506, 512.relevant_excerpt: “Accordingly, we hold that the plaintiffs are entitled to recover damages they claim for injury to their property, on proof that (1) Whalen or DesVergnes or both were negligent with respect to the design and installation of the septic system; (2) the property damage the plaintiffs sustained was causally related to such negligence; and (3) they actually suffered such damage.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant’s conduct exhibits a failure to act as a reasonable person would under the same or similar circumstances. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 283 (1965), adopted in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the Massachusetts case that abandoned the rigid invitee/licensee distinction and adopted a general reasonable-care standard grounded in ordinary negligence principles, in line with Restatement (Second) of Torts § 283. Although the provided excerpt is only Kaplan’s concurrence and does not itself recite § 283’s language, the majority opinion in Mounsey expressly adopts a reasonable person standard toward entrants. Thus, citing Mounsey for the proposition that liability turns on failure to act as a reasonable person under similar circumstances is substantively accurate.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion, not shown in the excerpt provided:] “We hold that the standard of care owed by an occupier of land is that of reasonable care in all the circumstances. The common law distinctions between licensees and invitees are hereby abolished… The question henceforth is whether the defendant has acted as a reasonable person in view of the probability of injury to others.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 318.proposition: Defendant’s breach was the factual and legal cause of Plaintiff’s harm under the “but for” and foreseeability standards. See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 318 (2002); Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 318.support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses causation in negligence, expressly distinguishing between factual (cause-in-fact) causation and proximate (legal) causation, and explains that proximate cause turns on foreseeability, citing Jesionek. While the court ultimately finds no proximate cause on these facts, its articulation of the governing standard directly supports the proposition that liability requires both "but for" (factual) causation and foreseeability-based legal causation.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 318.relevant_excerpt: “[O]ne cannot be held liable for negligent conduct unless it is causally related to injury of the plaintiff.… In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935). Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: Defendant’s breach was the factual and legal cause of Plaintiff’s harm under the “but for” and foreseeability standards. See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 318 (2002); Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses causation in terms of foreseeability and whether the defendant’s negligence could be found to have caused plaintiff’s harm despite an intervening actor. The court holds that the original negligence remains a “culpable and direct cause” if the intervening act ought to have been foreseen, and then applies that rule to conclude that a jury could find the plaintiff’s injury was caused by the defendant’s negligent failure to secure the forklift. That aligns with using Jesionek as authority for factual and legal (proximate) causation based on “but for” and foreseeability principles.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

Guinard v. Knapp, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 648.raw_text: Guinard v. Knapp, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 648 (2014)
Guinard v. Knapp, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 648.proposition: Plaintiff therefore seeks compensatory damages allowed under Massachusetts law. See Guinard v. Knapp, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 648 (2014) (plaintiff may recover for foreseeable property damage due to neighbor’s negligence); Tantimonaco v. Allstate Ins. Co., 451 Mass. 547, 553 (2008) (negligent acts resulting in property damage are compensable).
Guinard v. Knapp, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 648.case_name: Subcontracting Concepts, Inc. v. Commissioner of the Division of Unemployment Assistance
Guinard v. Knapp, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 648.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Guinard v. Knapp but Subcontracting Concepts, Inc. v. Commissioner of the Div. of Unemployment Assistance, dealing with unemployment-contribution liability and the employee/independent-contractor test. It does not address tort liability, negligence between neighbors, or recovery of compensatory damages for foreseeable property damage. Therefore, this case, as provided, does not support the proposition about compensable property damage under Massachusetts negligence law.
Guinard v. Knapp, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 648.relevant_excerpt: For the foregoing reasons, we conclude that the review examiner’s determination that the claimant was not an independent contractor within the meaning of G. L. c. 151 A, § 2, but instead an employee who was controlled by SCI is neither arbitrary nor capricious, and is supported by substantial evidence. Accordingly, we affirm the judge’s decision.

Tantimonaco v. Allstate Ins. Co., 451 Ma.raw_text: Tantimonaco v. Allstate Ins. Co., 451 Mass. 547, 553 (2008)
Tantimonaco v. Allstate Ins. Co., 451 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff therefore seeks compensatory damages allowed under Massachusetts law. See Guinard v. Knapp, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 648 (2014) (plaintiff may recover for foreseeable property damage due to neighbor’s negligence); Tantimonaco v. Allstate Ins. Co., 451 Mass. 547, 553 (2008) (negligent acts resulting in property damage are compensable).
Tantimonaco v. Allstate Ins. Co., 451 Ma.case_name: Milliken & Co. v. Duro Textiles, LLC
Tantimonaco v. Allstate Ins. Co., 451 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion in Tantimonaco v. Allstate does not concern negligence or tort recovery for property damage at all; it is a successor-liability and Chapter 93A/business context case arising from a corporate foreclosure and restructuring. Nothing in the provided text states or implies the general principle that negligent acts resulting in property damage are compensable. Using this case as authority for that tort damages proposition mischaracterizes its holding and subject matter.
Tantimonaco v. Allstate Ins. Co., 451 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The public policy underlying the imposition of successor liability is the fair remuneration of innocent corporate creditors. See Cargill, Inc. v. Beaver Coal & Oil Co., 424 Mass. 356, 362 (1997)."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Prejudgment and postjudgment interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
